name: iPool
tagline: The central component for search and distribution of content within Axel Springer.
body:
## API Documentation

[Axel Springer Ideas Engineering](http://www.asideas.de) is developing a general platform for distributing and providing content as a company-wide service.

**Contact us any time to get access to the iPool API:**

[benjamin.brandt@asideas.de](mailto:benjamin.brandt@asideas.de?subject=iPool%20API%20access) - [+49 151 440 47 219](callto://+4915144047219) - [@bennibrandt](https://twitter.com/bennibrandt)

The key component of this platform is the **iPool information hub** that offers functionality for

* storing
* semantic enrichment
* evaluation
* retrieval
* fully automated filtering

of various [Axel Springer content](http://www.axelspringer.de/media/Unsere-Angebote-Bezahlangebote-National_21139178.html).

The main purpose of this page is to describe the structure and application of the **iPool frontend API** embodying the user access tool for all content items stored and indexed within the iPool.

Documentation PDF V3: http://bit.ly/iPool_API_V3_Documentation

Swagger UI V3: https://ipool.s.asideas.de/swagger-ui

Frontend API V3 clients:

 * Java: https://github.com/ipool/iPoolAPIClient-java
 * ObjC/XCode: https://github.com/ipool/iPoolAPIClient-ObjC-XCode
 * Python: https://github.com/ipool/iPoolAPIClient-python
 * Ruby: https://github.com/ipool/iPoolAPIClient-ruby
 * JavaScript: https://github.com/ipool/iPoolAPIClient-JavaScript
 * angularJS: https://github.com/ipool/iPoolAPIClient-angularJS   
 
_This is a work in progress page._

## API Registration

Applications to the iPool API are approved individually for each new project. For the [Berlin Music Hack Day](http://musichackday.de/) following time limited OAuth access credentials are provided:

    Key: musichackday2014
    Secret: 276ea410-29fb-11e4-8c21-0800200c9a66

Above credentials will expire on **2014-12-31**. Long lived credentials are provided on request.

## API Examples

1) Retrieve content provided by music magazines:

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de:443/api/v3/search?limit=25&publisher="www.metal-hammer.de","www.musikexpress.de","www.rollingstone.de"
```

2) Find some content about your favourite singer Udo Lindenberg:

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de:443/api/v3/search?limit=25&q="udo lindenberg"
```

3) Find some pictures related to Udo Lindenberg:

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de:443/api/v3/search?limit=25&sources="escenic"&q=udo lindenberg

"contentReferences": [
{
  "binaryIdentifier": "ba510dc99b37854928cf553c96144caa",
  ...
}
```

4) Find articles about Udo Lindenbergs musical called "Hinterm Horizont":

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de:443/api/v3/search?persons="udo lindenberg"&limit=25&q="Hinterm Horizont"
```

Get a related article to Udo Lindenbergs musical:

```javascript
"relatedReferences": [
{
  "identifier": "cece43dc263ae3bca9385c8ddccb6890",
  "type": "ARTICLE"
},
...
]

	    
https://ipool.s.asideas.de:443/api/v3/related/cece43dc263ae3bca9385c8ddccb6890
```	

5) Retrieve music related content by category:

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de:443/api/v3/search?category="Musik"
```

## FAQ

**1) How can I use pagination?**

Pagination is a useful mechanism to get more results as specified by the limit parameter. Therefore, we simply exploit the offset parameter in conjunction with a certain limit value. Let us assume that we are interested in articles related to the singer Madonna. When our iPool system includes 1000 related articles, we can get a list of the first 100 ones via querying

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de/api/v3/search?persons="Madonna"&limit=100
```

For retrieving the next 100 articles (number 101 until number 200) of the list of all interesting articles we need to use an offset of 100 saying that we want to get the next 100 articles staring from position 100:

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de/api/v3/search?persons="Madonna"&offset=100&limit=100
```

To obtain the next 100 articles (number 201 until number 300) we shift the offset to 200:

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de/api/v3/search?persons="Madonna"&offset=200&limit=100
```

And so on.

**2) What is the difference between the hot topic and the trending endpoint?**

The hot topic endpoint determines topics that are mentioned most over all current documents. A time dimension is not taken into account.
Following example query gives hot topics that are related to the person Madonna, but not to the person Michael Jackson. To express such a query, we filter Madonna positively and Michael Jackson negatively in the persons parameter, respectively:

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de/api/v3/topics/hot?persons="Madonna",-"Michael Jackson"
```

In contrast, the trending endpoint retrieves topics with very quickly growing mention rates. That means, a topic can be trending in spite of having a relatively slow total number of mentions. In this case, it must show one of the best increasing rates.
The next example query returns the trending topics for the last 10 days (default value). Thereby, we split our overall interval in ten equal parts, i.e. one day per part. Based on these smaller intervals we internally calculate the increasing involved hot topics (default value).

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de/api/v3/topics/trending?numberOfRequests=10
```

**3) What is the difference between the limit and the numberOfHotTopics parameter for the trending endpoint?**

The limit parameter restricts the number of returned topics. Contrarily, the numberOfHotTopics parameter bounds the internal computation basis. As result, we are able to reduce critical calculations by adjusting this parameter.
The following query just consider the best 100 hot topics of the last 10 days to determine the trending ones:

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de/api/v3/topics/trending?numberOfHotTopics=100
```

**4) What does the parameter numberOfRequests mean?**

This parameter says how many times the specified interval is split for performing the underlying calculation of trending topics. For an example see above.

**5) How can I retrieve a picture?**

In order to download a specific picture you need either the object identifier or the external URL. Both entities are parts of the resulting JSON object achieved by a query sent to the search endpoint:

```javascript
"contentReferences": [ {
"binaryIdentifier": "31a79d4aa911d697d3bcd64fe07267d3",
"type": "PICTURE",
"title": "zschäpe 2",
"alternateText": "NSU Prozess",
"caption":"Beate Zschäpe am 100. Prozesstag im Gerichtssaal im
Oberlandesgericht in München", "copyrights": []
}, 
... 
{
"externalUrl": "http://brightcove01.brightcove.com/21/8385562001/201404/3458/8385562001_3417079759001_20140401-120624-Interview-Hannelore-Crolly-Welt-mL-2000.mp4,
"type": "VIDEO",
"title": "Zschäpe zeigt absolut keine Reue" 
}
]
```

Referenced media objects can either be downloaded directly by our API or from their original sources, see data field externalUrl. The availability of external media objects cannot be guaranteed.
For downloading the picture with the binary identifier 31a79d4aa911d697d3bcd64fe07267d3 we make use of the object endpoint via

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de/api/v3/object/31a79d4aa911d697d3bcd64fe07267d3?encodeBase64=true
```

The presences of binary identifiers and external URLs are depending on the given source and publisher of the considered article. For instance, all pictures of the source escenic can be achieved via our object endpoint. Contrarily, videos have to be downloaded directly by their respective URLs.

**6) How can I get an overview of all available keywords?**

We can get a list of all available keywords by taking advantage of the hot topic endpoint specifying the entityType as keywords:

```javascript
https://ipool.s.asideas.de/api/v3/topics/hot?entityTypes="keywords"
```
